Description: Peucedanum palustre
Marsh Hog's Fennel, Hogfennel
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae

Although no mention of toxicity has been seen for this species, skin contact with the sap of a number of members in this genus is said to cause photo-sensitivity and/or dermatitis in some people[65, 218]. They are also said to contain the alleged 'psychotroph' myristicine[218].
Fens and marshes, usually on calcareous soils[17].
Europe, including Britain, from Scandanavia south and east to Spain, the Altai and Urals.
No
Fully Hardy,Moist Soil,Wet Soil,Semi-shade,Full sun
https://pfaf.org/../Admin/PlantImages/PeucedanumPalustre2.jpg, https://pfaf.org/../Admin/PlantImages/PeucedanumPalustre.jpg

Peucedanum palustre is a BIENNIAL growing to 1.5 m (5ft).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 6.  It is in flower from July to September. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Bees, flies, Lepidoptera (Moths & Butterflies), beetles. The plant is self-fertile.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils and can grow in very alkaline soils. It can grow in  semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers  moist or  wet soil.
Selenium palustre. S. sylvestre.
Bog Garden;
Condiment: the various plants that are used as flavourings, either as herbs, spices or condiments.
The root can be used as a ginger substitute[2, 4, 17, 115, 183].

Antispasmodic: Relaxes muscular spasms and cramps, calming nervous irritation.,Epilepsy: Used in the treatment of Epilepsy - a disorder in which nerve cell activity in the brain is disturbed, causing seizures.,Stimulant: Excites or quickens activity of the physiological processes. Faster acting than a tonic but differing from a narcotic in that it does not give a false sense of well-being.

Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.Antispasmodic  Epilepsy  StimulantThe root is stimulant[4]. It is used in the treatment of epilepsy[4].
None known
An easily grown plant, it succeeds in any moisture-retentive soil in a sunny position[200]. Suitable for group plantings in the wild garden[200].

Seed - we have no information on this species but suggest sowing the seed in a cold frame as soon as it is ripe if this is possible otherwise in early spring. When they are large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and plant them out in the summer.
